Disserta√ß√£o (Mestrado em engenharia de processos qu√≠micos e bioqu√≠micos ‚Äì EPQB) ‚Äì Escola de Qu√≠mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, 2022) Buried pipes undergo a corrosion process, which can be avoided by applying the cathodic protection technique

However, this technique is susceptible to temporary failures, such as failures in rectifiers or theft of cables, in addition to permanent failures, such as soil leaching in the lower generatrix of the pipeline
During the functioning of the cathodic protection, oxygen is consumed by the cathodic reactions, generating hydroxyl ions that alkalize the medium
This pH increase can play a fundamental role in temporary failures, since the passive environment formed on the metal surface protects it against corrosion

In this work, experiments were carried out to study the behavior of parameters, such as potential and surface pH, during temporary failures, in addition to evaluating the mass loss in the case of temporary and permanent interruptions

For this, cathodic protection techniques were applied using three different electrochemical potentials, namely -850 mVCu/CuSO4, -1100 mVCu/CuSO4 and -1500 mVCu/CuSO4, so that the minimum protection potential, one intermediate potential, and an overprotection potential, respectively, could be studied since, in practice, can apply different levels of potential

In addition, used four test media: NS4 solution, industrial soil, industrial soil with urea and industrial soil with organic fertilizer, since pipes that are thousands of kilometers long can cross rural regions of plantations and pastures, where urea and manure can act as soil contaminants
Different on/off cycles were used to apply and interrupt the cathode current to simulate system failures
After testing, the surfaces of the samples were analyzed with a confocal microscope

The results in NS4 solution showed a high pH variation rate at the beginning and end of the cathodic protection application, due to the rapid diffusion of ions in this medium, unlike the tests with soil, which presented slower variation rates, due to the capacity of the soil to retain ions

With regard to the depolarization results, it was possible to observe that, after interruption of the cathode current, the depolarization times in NS4 solution showed very close values, regardless of the time and applied potential, while in the three types of soil it was observed that the The more cathodic the applied potential and the longer the cathodic protection application time, the longer the depolarization time
The immersion results showed that it is possible to obtain a reduction in the corrosion rate with the previous application of cathodic protection for some studied systems
